This tool dries and straightens simultaneously from wet to dry and is engineered to create a natural straight finish for multiple hair types, with no hot plates or heat damage.u00b9.Features:- Airflow is projected downwards at a 45u00b0 angle to create the tension needed to align hair for a smooth end styleu2014with less damage and breakage.2.Key Controls:- Two styling modes: Wet to Dry and Dry mode.In the Box:- Dyson Airstrait
how_to_use: Suggested Usage:.Straightening Wet Hair:.-Start with towel-dried hair..-Select Wet mode. .-Select maximum airflow and high temperature..-Lock arms. .-Rough dry the roots..-Once roots are dry, unlock arms and select desired airflow and temperature. .-Dry and straighten hair from root to tip in sections..-Once your hair is dry, select Cool mode..-Set your style with cool air for shiny finish...Straightening Dry Hair:.-Select Dry mode to touch-up or refresh your style. .-Select desired airflow and temperature..-Boost mode, the highest heat, is available if required..-Straighten hair from root to tip in sections..-Once straightened, select Cool mode and set your style with cool air for shiny finish.

reviews.review_text: I have long, fine hair that has a natural wave with a bit of frizz. Since the pandemic, I have mostly just pulled it back in a knot because the routine of drying it and then using the flatiron was too time-consuming.   To be fully transparent, I have the blow dryer and the vacuum at home, and while they're both great, IMO, they're not great enough to warrant the price tag. That being said, I was intrigued by the Airstrait because I could use one tool. Luckily, I have given it as a gift and have two words u2013 LOVE IT!  My routine is so much simpler now and I've been wearing my hair down every day. Out of the shower I pop a towel on my head while I do my skincare and any makeup I'm wearing that day. When I'm done, I pop off the towel, comb through my hair with a wide-tooth comb, put on a dab of heat protector, and hold the straightener closed to do a quick - literally one minute - dry of my roots so they are damp, not wet. Then, starting in sections, I dry/iron my hair, and my whole head is done in 7 minutes.  I have thin hair, so I can't speak to how long it would take for someone with thick hair, but I was impressed with the speed. It isn't quite as flat/straight as a traditional flat iron, but for me, that's a plus, as my hair has more volume this way. I also use it the second day on dry hair to smooth out any kinks from sleep, and it does the job in probably 4 minutes.  Cons: Obviously, the price is crazy. It's heavy to hold, and it's pretty noisy.  But for me, this is 1000% worth it. Literally, my favorite hair tool ever.

reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I am not the kind of girl to spend a lot of money on hair. My blowdryer is an old $20 Revlon from who knows when and my Chi hair straightener was my splurge item at $100. I have thick, dark, medium, 2c curl pattern hair and dread the hour it takes after a shower to style it with a round brush and hair dryer if I want it straight to avoid having to put in the cocktail of product to avoid a frizzy mop. I've tried the Revlon One Step Volumizer tool and it only saved me 5ish minutes.   With 15% rewards for my VIB membership, I thought why not try it? If it did not work in the slightest, it was going to go right back. If I like it, I get a little bit off discount.   This thing is high-tech, has a neat cleaning function every time you turn it on, and shuts off when you set it on the counter. There are options for straightening dry hair or wet hair and 3 heat settings and one cool setting.   At nearly $500, I wasn't here to mess around. I got out of the shower, hair sopping wet, tossed in a bit of smoothing creme, and set this thing to stun (highest heat setting 275 degrees on wet hair mode). It took me less than 25 minutes to get my entire head completely dry and straight. Compared to the usual hour, this is a gamechanger for me. My hair was straight with still some volume which is how I prefer it, but I suspect if I wanted it stick straight, I could just spend another 5-10 min quick pass through with my hair straightener.   Cons: It's heavier than a typical hair straightener but the strain for me is far less than from my round brush and hair dryer. It is expensive and I am privileged to be able to splurge on this at this point in my life.   Time is valuable to me, and with an extra 35 minutes of my life back, it is worth the price.

reviews.review_title: Here is your in-depth curly hair review!

reviews.review_text: I have type 3B curls. I really didn't have high hopes for this, but dang, it work wonders. It's like magic, I can't figure out the tech, it's pretty awesome. So, a few things of note. It's not going to give you a large, beautiful blow out. This is much more akin to using a straightener, which makes sense. My Revlon One-Step gives me all the 80's height and volume, this does not. But it's not far off. It still gives me a decent volume boost, and coming from the view of a straightener, it gives a heck of a lot more volume than any straightener can.  Now, for the straightening of the curls - it does it! It works wonders. It straightens my hair  perfectly, quickly, and with less heat damage. There's still heat, this 'no heat damage' is misleading, but it's much less than traditional irons or dryers. It's magic, that's all I can say. I grab a bunch of hair, run this through twice, and any evidence of curl is gone. I'm truly impressed. I am going to miss my Revlon One Step, but dang this straightens my hair so great with less damage.   I've used it on wet hair and dry hair, and works great on both with the same settings. FTR, I towel dry my hair, add product, and then use this. I also add more product after because I do get frizz from it.  Potential cons (and cons is strong word here): It's not frizz free. I still get frizz. You still need your heat protectant and frizz control products. It's heavy. Heavier than a blow dryer. Not a deal breaker, but this is certainly a solid piece of machinery. And it's huge, it takes up a lot of space in my drawer now. The cord is kind of annoying, it's heavy duty and has a large piece that can get stuck on the lip of my counter. And it probably accounts for 1/4 of the weight of this thing!  Aside from all that, it's 5 stars. It does what it says. If it didn't, I 100% would not be keeping it for $700!!
The only tool you will ever need for wet to dry pin straight hair. Period. Hair will feel fresh and natural for days. Cannot use for any other styling.

reviews.review_text: So I know itu2019s very pricey for a hair dryer but personally I think itu2019s worth the investment. The plates themselves do not heat up like a flat iron, the plates clamp the air that then circulates hot air, which I feel also helps if you're trying to minimize heat styling on your hair (still use a heat protectant though). I used to have to blow dry my hair and then straighten it, but not anymore. I honestly don't even use my flat iron anymore, so it saves me time when styling and space in my luggage when I travel because this is the only styling tool I bring if I want straight hair. I will say though that this tool does not give you that salon blowout look, so if that's what you're hoping for, this isn't it, because it's not designed to deliver those results. It's meant to dry wet hair straight and does a really good job of that. I do think the results are a little more bouncy and voluminous than you would get with a flat iron, so if you want a pin straight sleek look, you can definitely go in with your flat iron after.

reviews.review_text: I have owned the Airstrait for about 3 months (I purchased it directly from Dyson). I was hesitant to purchase it initially because it is expensive, and I was highly skeptical. I was shocked to see the result from just a small piece. I have since used the Airstrait on Wet-to-dry, air-dried, and touchups. I LOVE it! My hair feels much healthier and doesn't ever get that burnt hair smell. The Airstrait doesn't really save time over a flat iron, but it will protect your hair from extreme heat and metal plates pulling on your strands. The key to success with this tool is patience. You can't rush through your hair, and you need to spend a little time on the ends to be sure they are smooth all the way through - wet to dry requires 3-4 passes. My style doesn't hold as well in humidity as it would with a flat iron, but I feel better about doing touchups with the Airstrait over a flat iron. Overall, I could not be happier with my purchase!
